Getting started with NuGet 5.8
NuGet 5.8 is included in Visual Studio 16.8 and .NET 5.0 out of the box. You can also download NuGet 5.8 for Windows, macOS, and Linux as a standalone executable.

FeedItems.Summary: We are excited to announce that nuget.org now supports package deprecation. This has been a long standing ask that will help the ecosystem use supported packages. As a package publisher on nuget.org,...

# Gallery

Changes:

11/04:
[A11y] Manage members of an organization - responsive after reflowing(#8301)

11/09:
Dropping the narration completely for absent signature and deprecation information (#8309)
Removed unused localIP member of CloudAuditingService. (#8306)
Accept packages with a minClientVersion of 5.8.0 (#8317)

11/10:
Just break word (#8310)

11/11:
Add netstandard2.1 support to NuGetGallery.Core and NuGet.Services.Entities (#8320)
[SAS Token] Fallback when permissions cannot be use on container creation. (#8315)

11/13:
Add restricted API for soft deleting packages (#8290)
Switch to NuGetTestData for static test packages (#8324)

11/23:
Move to new build tools (#8331)
Add * by required field (#8328)
Add description for readmore (#8333)
Only allowed one scroll bar when zooming in (#8330)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Layout page change has broken status razor build" (#8318) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This change: 
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8256/files
Specifically this line:
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/blob/master/src/NuGetGallery/Views/Shared/Gallery/Layout.cshtml#L35
...will now block updating the NuGetGallery submodule in https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Services.Status. If you build the repo with an updated submodule, it will complete, but the default page has a dependency on layout.cshtml which causes the razor compile to fail at this line (looks like ViewBag is unknown).

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Is there a "hidden" property that can be set for contentFiles?" (#10355) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
When reporting a [VS problem](https://developercommunity2.visualstudio.com/t/Solution-Explorer-is-showing-nuget-packa/1271799?port=1025&fsid=47c8a867-5f1b-4af4-ab23-1a1b841d2219&entry=myfeedback#TPIN-N1276054), I was told that the reason for the unwanted behavior (contentFiles showing up as project files in sln explorer) was that a package was incorrectly authored and should have included the files as "hidden" instead of "contentFiles". 

I cant find a hidden attribute or element in the nuspec.xsd.  Is the info I was given correct and the documentation is out of date, or is the opposite true?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Add GenerateRestoreGraphFile in static graph restore to improve debugability. " (#10365) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Related: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10307

Completing this task also makes `NuGet.exe static graph` possible.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Proposal of consolidating user wide NuGet.Config files on Linux/Mac" (#10364) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Application.exe.config being overwritten during build" (#10282) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity2.visualstudio.com/t/Applicationexeconfig-being-overwritten/610276)._ --- During the build of our application, app.config gets copied to <application>.exe.config, this is then overwritten with a binding redirect. This is only happening on two out of four machines, on two it builds as normal, copying the app.config file to <application>.exe.config. On the other two, <application>.exe.config just contains a binding redirect after the application has built. We have narrowed it down to the reference of an external dependency, when the use of this dependency is removed, the app.config is copied correctly on build. Is this a Visual Studio setting that is trying to put in a binding redirect, as it can't find the correct version of the dependency? (I have tried disabling auto binding redirect, it didn't work) --- ### Original Comments #### Feedback Bot on 6/18/2019, 02:53 AM:

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

#### Jin Zhao [MSFT] on 6/19/2019, 01:36 AM:

Thank you for your feedback! For us to investigate this further, could you provide more details:

  1. what's the contain in you app.config?
  2. What external dependence is reference in your project, how it used?

It will be better if you can provide your repro solution.

We look forward to hearing from you!

#### Caillin Spain on 6/19/2019, 02:26 AM:
  1. what is contained in your app.config?

The app.config contains required dependency versions which are used in checks on application boot. When it is overwritten, it is overwritten with a binding redirect for a dependency which our application uses.

2.What external dependencies are referenced in your project, how are they used?

The dependency that the binding redirect is for is Newtonsoft, it is used by our application and also by another third party dependency, which we use in our app.

Is there a setting in Visual Studio to add auto binding redirects, other than the setting in the csproj, as I have disabled that.

#### Feedback Bot on 6/19/2019, 07:25 PM:

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

#### Jin Zhao [MSFT] on 6/19/2019, 07:25 PM: (private comment, text removed) #### dan.carter on 7/4/2019, 07:46 AM:

Any update on this? I'm getting exactly the same behaviour in VS2019. On my machine the config file in the bin\Debug\ does not match the app.config file in the project, but this is not happening for my colleages on the same solution.

#### Feedback Bot on 8/7/2019, 06:34 PM: We want to let you know that this problem will likely be closed in 60 days. We set priority based on severity, similar reports, and the overall impact on users and scenarios. We've also learned that reports without fresh activity could indicate that the problem isn't a problem anymore. One of our goals is to give you more transparency around these decisions as resolving every problem that gets reported isn't always possible. Your feedback is essential for helping us decide what needs the most attention, so please keep upvoting and commenting if you think that we need to make this a higher priority . #### Caillin Spain on 9/25/2019, 07:38 AM:

Update: I am now using a new PC with a fresh install of Visual Studio and have all the settings as before (the same as the rest of my team) and I am still getting this issue, so that's now 3 PC's in our team with this problem. I am unable to run my application without using a nasty work around (post build step to overwrite the exe.config with the app.config contents), other people are reporting this same problem, so please continue to investigate.

#### Feedback Bot on 3/31/2020, 05:35 PM:

Thank you for sharing your feedback! Our teams prioritize action on product issues with broad customer impact. See details at: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/ide/report-a-problem?view=vs-2019#faq. In case you need answers to common questions or need assisted support, be sure to use https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/vs/support/. We’ll keep you posted on any updates to this feedback.

#### Caillin Spain on 8/27/2020, 06:14 AM:

Any updates? Over a year later and still getting this problem...

--- ### Original Solutions (no solutions)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "msbuild restore doesn't import all packages" (#10347) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
---
**Issue moved from dotnet/msbuild#5908**
- Please respond to @zdavidsen.

---

_From @zdavidsen on Tuesday, November 24, 2020 4:06:10 PM_

<!-- NOTE: The MSBuild team receives a lot of issues and we need to prioritize them accordingly. Please understand that we may not get to your issue for some time. -->
<!-- This is a template that helps us provide quicker feedback. Please use any relevant sections and delete anything you don't need. -->

<!--
* Here are some useful links to help you figure out what's wrong.
* Our wiki: https://github.com/microsoft/msbuild/blob/master/documentation/wiki/Home.md
* General Help: https://github.com/microsoft/msbuild/blob/master/documentation/wiki/Something's-wrong-in-my-build.md
* Tips & Tricks: https://github.com/microsoft/msbuild/blob/master/documentation/wiki/MSBuild-Tips-%26-Tricks.md
-->

### Issue Description
<!--
* Please include a clear and concise description of the problem.
-->
(Posting on behalf of a coworker, since I'm the designated build script maintainer)

We have a common msbuild script/project that we use in a number of repositories which requires a couple of Nuget packages (an internal package and MSBuild Community Tasks).  Recently, one of my coworkers has started having problems with the project, where it will restore correctly but won't import MSBuild Community tasks (it does import the internal package).  The fun part is that the exact same project will build on any of our other machines and our build server; it only fails on coworker's machine.

Any ideas what could be causing this?

Here's a slightly stripped down copy of the common build script, and the generated .props and .targets files from both my machine and the coworker's.
[MSBuildFiles.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/msbuild/files/5591156/MSBuildFiles.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "November dry run for custom V2 OData query deprecation" (#48) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
 
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	· **Nov. 11, 2020** – 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	· **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**  – 48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
 
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	· UTC-9 to UTC-2 – [Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
	· UTC-1 to UTC+6 – [Yellow test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Yellow+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3915&ah=4)
	· UTC+7 to UTC-10 – [Blue test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Blue+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3909&ah=4)

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
 
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	· **Nov. 11, 2020** – 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	· **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**  – 48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe.
